page.title: 06WILDLIFE ON BISHOPSTONE DOWN
page.content: THERE HAVE BEEN SIGHTINGS THIS SUMMER OF BADGERS DEER FOXES HARES RABBITS WEASELS JACKDAWS MAGPIES PARTRIDGES AND PHEASANTS.ALSO SEAGULLS FROM THE SEVERN ESTUARY.DUE TO MODERN FARMING METHODS-SCRUBBING OUT OF HEDGES AND DENSE CROPPING OF FIELDS,WILD PARTRIDGE ARE NOT SO PLENTIFUL AS IN THE PAST.LESS DENSE HEDGES AND A DEARTH OF GAMEKEEPERS RESULTS IN MANY EGGS BEING EATEN BY WEASELS AND MAGPIES WHO GO UNMOLESTED.SOME ENGLISH PARTRIDGE HAVE BEEN REARED LOCALLY,AND IT IS HOPED TO RELEASE THESE INTO THE WILD AT THE END OF THE WINTER. BUTTERFLIES SEEN ON THE DOWNS- SMALL AND LARGE TORTOISESHELL,PEACOCK,RED ADMIRAL, MEADOW BROWN AND AN OCCASIONAL CHALK BLUE.
